toc.para: This Solaris Trusted Extensions Administrator’s Procedures guide provides procedures for managing users, zones, devices, and hosts that are labeled with Solaris Trusted Extensions software.

note.para: This Solaris release supports systems that use the SPARC and x86 families of processor architectures: UltraSPARC, SPARC64, AMD64, Pentium, and Xeon EM64T. The supported systems appear in the Solaris 10 Hardware Compatibility List at . This document cites any implementation differences between the platform types.

itemizedlist.para: In this document these x86 related terms mean the following:

listitem.para: “x86” refers to the larger family of 64-bit and 32-bit x86 compatible products.
“x64” points out specific 64-bit information about AMD64 or EM64T systems.
“32-bit x86” points out specific 32-bit information about x86 based systems.

note.para: For supported systems, see the Solaris 10 Hardware Compatibility List.

sect1.title: Who Should Use This Book
sect1.para: This book is used by administrators who are able to assume an administrative role. This book describes how to do administrative tasks that are particular to Trusted Extensions.

itemizedlist.para: Administrators should be familiar with Solaris administration. In addition, you should understand the following:

listitem.para: Basic concepts and procedures for using a host that is configured with Trusted Extensions, as described in the Solaris Trusted Extensions User’s Guide .
How administrative tasks are divided among roles at your site.

sect1.title: How the Solaris Trusted Extensions Books Are Organized
sect1.para: The Solaris Trusted Extensions 1.0 documentation set supplements the documentation for the Solaris Express release. Review both sets of documentation to get a more complete understanding of Solaris Trusted Extensions. The Solaris Trusted Extensions documentation set consists of the following books.

entry.para: Provides an overview of the differences between Trusted Solaris 8 software, Solaris Express software, and Solaris Trusted Extensions 1.0 software.
Provides Solaris Trusted Extensions man pages.
Describes the basic features of Solaris Trusted Extensions. This book contains a glossary.
Lists known problems and describes workarounds for Solaris Trusted Extensions 1.0 software.

olink.citetitle: Solaris Trusted Extensions Installation and Configuration

entry.para: Describes how to plan for, install, and configure Solaris Trusted Extensions.
Shows how to perform specific administration tasks.
Describes how to develop applications with Solaris Trusted Extensions.
Provides information about how to specify label components in the label encodings file.

olink.citetitle: Compartmented Mode Workstation Labeling: Encodings Format

entry.para: Describes the syntax used in the label encodings file. The syntax enforces the various rules for well-formed labels for a system.

sect1.title: Documentation, Support, and Training
sect1.para: The Sun web site provides information about the following additional resources:

sect1.title: Typographic Conventions
sect1.para: The following table describes the typographic conventions that are used in this book.

entry.para: The names of commands, files, and directories, and onscreen computer output
Use ls a to list all files.
What you type, contrasted with onscreen computer output
Placeholder: replace with a real name or value
The command to remove a file is rm filename.
Book titles, new terms, and terms to be emphasized
Read Chapter 6 in the User's Guide.
A cache is a copy that is stored locally.
Note: Some emphasized items appear bold online.
